unnormalised: Subject: Air Quality - Is Delhi's air REALLY that bad, or is it all hype?
normalised: Subject: Air Quality - Is Delhi's air really that bad, or is it all hype?

unnormalised: Okay, so I'm from Delhi, and every winter, the air quality becomes a huge talking point. News channels are screaming about AQI levels, folks are coughing like crazy, and everyone's stocking up on N-95 masks. Is it REALLY that bad, or is it just the media blowing things out of proportion?
normalised: Okay, so I'm from Delhi, and every winter, the air quality becomes a huge talking point. News channels are screaming about A Q I levels, folks are coughing like crazy, and everyone's stocking up on N-ninety five masks. Is it really that bad, or is it just the media blowing things out of proportion?

unnormalised: Honestly, it's bad. REALLY bad. I mean, you can literally SMELL the difference on certain days, especially around Diwali. Last year, on November 4th, 2023, the PM2.5 levels were off the charts! Breathing felt like trying to filter air through a brick.
normalised: Honestly, it's bad. Really bad. I mean, you can literally smell the difference on certain days, especially around Diwali. Last year, on november fourth, two thousand and twenty three, the P M two point five levels were off the charts! Breathing felt like trying to filter air through a brick.

unnormalised: But it's not JUST Delhi. Think about Kanpur, or even smaller industrial cities. The pollution from factories, vehicle emissions, and burning of crop residue contribute significantly. I remember reading a report from IIT Kanpur suggesting that a significant portion of Delhi's pollution actually comes from outside the city.
normalised: But it's not just Delhi. Think about Kanpur, or even smaller industrial cities. The pollution from factories, vehicle emissions, and burning of crop residue contribute significantly. I remember reading a report from I I T Kanpur suggesting that a significant portion of Delhi's pollution actually comes from outside the city.

unnormalised: What's frustrating is that we KNOW the causes. We have policies, like the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP), but implementation is often slow and ineffective. It's usually around 09:00 hrs that the news starts reporting the 'severe' air quality.
normalised: What's frustrating is that we know the causes. We have policies, like the Graded Response Action Plan (G R A P), but implementation is often slow and ineffective. It's usually around nine zero zero hours that the news starts reporting the 'severe' air quality.

unnormalised: Of course, not every day is a doomsday scenario. There are days when the air feels cleaner, especially after a good rainfall. My Dadi always says, "The Ganga maiya will cleanse everything eventually!" But relying on divine intervention isn't a sustainable solution.
normalised: Of course, not every day is a doomsday scenario. There are days when the air feels cleaner, especially after a good rainfall. My Dadi always says, "The Ganga maiya will cleanse everything eventually!" But relying on divine intervention isn't a sustainable solution.

unnormalised: We need better public transport, stricter regulations on industries, and a collective effort to reduce emissions. Maybe even invest in giant air purifiers like they have in China? The government has introduced initiatives like BS-VI emission standards, but results take time.
normalised: We need better public transport, stricter regulations on industries, and a collective effort to reduce emissions. Maybe even invest in giant air purifiers like they have in China? The government has introduced initiatives like B S-V I emission standards, but results take time.

unnormalised: So, is the hype justified? I’d say yes, especially during peak pollution season. My niece, Anya, had to miss school on 26/01/2024 due to breathing problems. It’s affecting our health and our quality of life. It’s time we take it seriously. What are your thoughts on this?
